title: If we reverted the mastery system
body:
It would drastically change the game, I know that **but**

Everyone and Yasuo's mom would stop abusing Fervor.

Bursting someone would actually be something to achieve instead of mashing your face, proc thunderlords and zone your enemy since they've been chunked so hard.

Tanks could do their job slightly better (I'm looking at you, free 7% armor or magic pen)

Tanks would want Veteran Scars since it would give its old 3% instead of flat 50.

Damage overall would be **reduced**.

tl;dr: Keystone Masteries grabbed us by the throat and said, "do damage or you're useless."

...Maybe we could also buy green crystals on a wooden stick that could grant us vision for 75 gold too, but I doubt Riot is that generous.

replies.body: Keystones were a mistake.
Agreed

According to the community, the previous masteries were as well as there were stat boosts in there that made the difference but an invisible one at that and everyone complained how that was the exact problem. Riot listened and fleshed out the power of masteries in the form of damages you can see the impact of and they aren't as strong as doubling your kit's damage. They are small, visible damage boosts that have a lot of variability between champions that use them and it's also understandable that not every champions is optimized to using all of them equally.

Old masteries were optimized for all champions more or less (depending on the damage type) and you weren't changing them frequently. These masteries, including the Keystones are intended to be easily changed on the fly, depending on the needs of your champion. Not every marksman needs Fervor. You can use Thunderlord's, DFT, Bloodlust or even Stormraider's (if you're a marksman that deals a ton of damage, fast).

So, where's our apology?
No, they're just poorly done.  If the keystones weren't ridiculously overpowered, they would be great.

Keystones were a brilliant idea for giving meaningful feedback to you choice in which mastery tree to invest in, rather than simply (and mindlessly) taking on 3% bonus damage as the 21st point. Keystones are interesting and allow for a MUCH greater amount of customization. HOWEVER, certain keystones (most notably fervor, but grasp of the undying is slightly guilty, as well) are entirely overpowered, and adding to that power is the fact that trinity force was changed to synergize incredibly well with it (probably unintentional, but still, the AS increase to triforce made irelia op with fervor and opened the bruiser yasuo build path). If riot just scaled back the free damage on fervor and scaled up the defensive masteries (ie defensive bonuses, not just keystones) I think this mastery system would be seen as a 100% improvement over the constant 21/9/0 system.

Nah masteries are fine and could give actual meaningful decisions if riot would care about them. 
So far they tuned them a bit with buffs and nerfs and that's it. 
Instead they should have devoted themselves this season to make them actually perfect instead of changing everything at once.

For example, several burst mages like {{champion:61}} {{champion:103}} {{champion:1}} would have wayyy less damage and poke without thunderlords, to the point where they would be just garbage. I'm so happy to see people finally understanding how much damage the mastery update did to the _already-damaged_ game.  Once again, the best course of action is to revert to the old masteries that _didn't_ break anyone, that _didn't_ warp the balance around their existence, and _didn't_ need to be changed constantly when someone abuses a new keystone, also indirectly nerfing the champions who depended on it and didn't abuse it.

There is only one problem: most champions and items have suffered changes due to the mastery system. Reverting it would mean a crap load of changes in a short period, which is more likely to brake stuff than to fix it up again.
Things always break when they add anything to the game, this might be a change for preseason, hopefully not a midseason thing.
If they are going for big changes like removing Key Stones it's most likely pre-season stuff.
I'm fine if it takes a while to revert the balance accommodation changes.  I think it would take even longer to find a decent spot for the masteries.

Was the old mastery system really worth keeping, though? I'm not defending the new mastery system, and in fact I'd like to see it removed, but I also don't think there really ever was truly interesting gameplay or strategy to the previous masteries either. At this point, it probably might be better to just call it quits, scrap masteries entirely and put whatever choice they bring into in-game itemization and champion buffs. A little extra gold could go a long way into opening avenues for more stats or unique effects at level 1.
